original_title: Sri Lanka’s CEB and LECO borrows from ADB under Treasury guarantees
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s state-run Ceylon Electricity Board and Lanka Electric Company has borrowed 230 million dollars from the Asian Development Bank for hydro power and to upgrade the grid for renewable energy under Treasury guarantees, a statement said.

A 200 million dollar loan from ADB’s Ordinary Capital Resources will be taken through the Power System Strengthening and Renewable Energy Integration Project to integrate more renewable energy projects and maintain power system reliability.
Due to the intermittency or unreliability of renewable energy, power grids face high levels of volatility and needs extensive capital investments to withstand shocks.

The project will focus on strengthening and modernizing of climate-resilient transmission and distribution network to facilitate renewable integration and including enhanced renewable energy integration and grid management capabilities, the Finance Ministry said.
The ADB said in an earlier statement that 150 million dollars will go to the CEB and 50 million dollars to the Lanka Electric Company, which is a distributions subsidiary of the main utility.
Ceylon Electricity Board’s General Manager K G R F Comester, and Lanka Electricity Company’s Chairman Janaka Aluthge signed the loan agreements.
The CEB also borrowed another 30 million dollars in two 15 million tranches from the ADB’s Ordinary Capital Resources window.
The first tranche will go to complete the construction and post-construction activities of the Moragolla Hydropower Project.
The second tranche will be obtained later to implement the projects aimed to complement the renewable energy development.

Guarantee Agreements were signed on December 19 between the Government of Sri Lanka and the Asian Development Bank K M Mahinda Siriwardana, Secretary, Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development, Takafumi Kadono, Country Director, ADB Sri Lanka Residence Mission.
Sri Lanka’s central government used to borrow money directly on behalf of some state enterprises which had their own revenues and on-lend the funds.

However, macroeconomists who ran the Treasury in the recent past has made some agencies which do not have revenues or profits like the Road Development Authority to borrow with Treasury guarantees, distorting actual central government debt and deficits, critics say.

A limit on Treasury guarantees set in a Fiscal Management Law was also raised by amendments. Bandula Gunawardana, who has Deputy Finance Minister when the law was brought, and later rubber stamped the lifting of ceilings has said macroeconomists misled the parliament.
The ADB has said it was loaning the funds following reforms to ensure cost recovery pricing and competitive procurement of renewable energy.
In Sri Lanka and elsewhere the renewable activists successfully lobbied to avoid competitive tender. (Colombo/Dec19/2024)
